Can you picture the scene: a middle-aged man leaning
towards the lecture table in Remsen 1, eyes strained at
the waves of chairs arching upwards, voice cracked just
enough to feign spontaneity? Yes, the George Benton
Show last Friday was a great soap opera. The faculty
applauded loud, several professors stood up, even a few
cried, "We believe you."
Benton (color him Lancelot) now portrays himself as
the unsong hero who led his professors against a fat,
fire-breathing Central Administration. Last November
the dean brandished his sword at Homewood House by
declaring a ten per cent faculty reduction well-knowing
that the faculty would demand similar cuts in the
Central Administration. The crusade had begun, and
four months later Gordon's Administration was
trimmed the designated amount.
But where does this now leave Dr. Benton? With very
unimpressive figures despite his maudlin rhetoric..
Homewood's budget has been cut 6.5 per cent--all in

And it was the dean's timidness at investigating the
faculty's own fiefdoms (that,as Biology currently shows,
also contain a lot of wasted potential) which was
actually applauded on Friday.
Benton's adament refusal to disclose the expenditure
breakdowns by department forbids everybody except
the dean and maybe the Academic Council from
studying whether Hopkins is pouring its money into the
right barrels. The University last year paid $3.8 million
out of its general funds to Homewood's science
departments and $2.9 million to the liberal arts even
though the 4,000 full-time student population is divided
equally between the two areas. Within the next two
years 23 full-time professors that were formerly
financed by foundation grants will have to be paid by the
University, costing $500,000 extra annually. Have such
matters been considered during the budget talks or
discarded by the push of immediate problems? Benton
has indicated that he has not studied these questions
which is an indicator of Benton's success during his first

cut enrollment and (again donning his mock-heroic
mask) "personally persuade" his faculty-friends to
teach more. When asked for more details to this rather
simpleminded scheme, Benton replies like a recording:
"This is a sensitive area ... this is a soft spot. . . one has
to proceed slowly." Such statements bring back
memories of Kimball's do-nothing days. And since
